<item>
 <title>Listen: The Stone Roses - 'All For One'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/listen-the-stone-roses-all-for-one</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Stone%20Roses_0.jpg?itok=76sGPHXf"><a href="/news/listen-the-stone-roses-all-for-one"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Stone%20Roses_0.jpg?itok=76sGPHXf" width="600" height="398" alt="The Stone Roses" title="The Stone Roses" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Yep, it&#039;s here.</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>The Stone Roses</strong> have released new single 'All For One'.</p>
<p>The band's first release in two decades, the single was announced following a cryptic poster campaign.</p>
<p>Available to purchase <u><strong><a href="po.st/AllForOneiT">HERE</a></strong></u> you can listen below.</p>
<p><iframe allowtransparency="true" frameborder="0" height="380" src="https://embed.spotify.com/?uri=spotify:album:1rceGUzKIZ0M1BM21oKWwU" width="300"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:14:18 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89883 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/listen-the-stone-roses-all-for-one#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>The Future Is Nordic: Spot Festival 2016</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/The_Hearing_Filtenborg_Fotografi_foto2.jpg?itok=h1Ip-dyp"><a href="/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/The_Hearing_Filtenborg_Fotografi_foto2.jpg?itok=h1Ip-dyp" width="628" height="419" alt="The Hearing (Credit: Filtenborg)" title="The Hearing (Credit: Filtenborg)" /></a></div><div class="field-item odd" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/20160501-Molly-Radar-Kim-Sternkopf%40HeartMatterArtworks-12.jpg?itok=MQJQO6fZ"><a href="/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/20160501-Molly-Radar-Kim-Sternkopf%40HeartMatterArtworks-12.jpg?itok=MQJQO6fZ" width="628" height="420" alt="Molly (Credit: Kim Sternkopf)" title="Molly (Credit: Kim Sternkopf)" /></a></div><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/20160501-Narcosatanicos-Radar-Kim-Sternkopf%40HeartMatterArtworks-07.jpg?itok=l9WQ1E8l"><a href="/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/20160501-Narcosatanicos-Radar-Kim-Sternkopf%40HeartMatterArtworks-07.jpg?itok=l9WQ1E8l" width="628" height="386" alt="Narcosantanicos (Credit: Kim Sternkopf)" title="Narcosantanicos (Credit: Kim Sternkopf)" /></a></div><div class="field-item odd" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Kelvin.JPG?itok=d18sYrWN"><a href="/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Kelvin.JPG?itok=d18sYrWN" width="628" height="419" alt="Kelvin (Credit: Si Hawkins)" title="Kelvin (Credit: Si Hawkins)" /></a></div><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Lowly%2C%20foto%20-%20Mikkel%20Elming%203.jpg?itok=XW5etPrq"><a href="/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Lowly%2C%20foto%20-%20Mikkel%20Elming%203.jpg?itok=XW5etPrq" width="628" height="942" alt="Lowly (Credit: Mikkel Elming)" title="Lowly (Credit: Mikkel Elming)" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">The finest spots from the Danish fest...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>We have seen the future, and it is Danish. And Finnish. And Norwegian.</p>
<p>It’s definitely Nordic, anyway, on the evidence of this year’s Spot Festival, which threw up so many memorable shows that our Top Five ended up as a Top Eight. Great.</p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p><strong>Farveblind</strong><br />
	The Chemical Younger-Brothers. In their civvies these youthful Danes don’t look like rampant dancefloor noise monsters, but lord-have-mercy-on-our-souls they make some din. Tremendously chunky block-rocking beats from a live drummer and a wild-eyed kid in a shellsuit top who twiddles nobs, bangs things and whips the audience into a proper frenzy. Farveblind means ‘colourblind’, but is curiously tricky to memorise, as Clash discovered on the way to that gig, shouting “I’m going to father-something!” across a crowded lobby, which raised a few eyebrows, understandably.</p>
<p><strong>The Hearing</strong><br />
	An admirably single-minded, multi-tattooed talent, Helsinki’s Ringa Manner is a one-woman electropop wizard. Or should that be wizardess? Certainly not a witch, anyway: her candid between-song patter is almost as entertaining as the tracks themselves, as she explains what each is about after lengthily wondering aloud which one to play next. And those songs? Quirky, catchy nuggets of joy. Also heartily recommended is a trip to her tumblr – thehearing.tumblr.com - where Ringa documents her music-biz dealings via the medium of self-made comics. Marvellous.</p>
<p><strong>Ary</strong><br />
	A rangier performer than Ringa, this mesmerising Norwegian electropop singer only started making music two years ago, which is hard to fathom given how bizarrely impressive her live show is. But then stage-right is Ary’s secret weapon on guitar, fellow singer-songwriter Fay Wildhagen, who looks and acts a lot like the wonderful Wendy Melvoin from Prince’s old band. Y’know, from the ‘Kiss’ video, which does come to mind during this gig. Together, Ary and Wildhagen are the new Prince. You heard it here first.</p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p><img alt="" src="http://admin.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/field/image/20160501-Molly-Radar-Kim-Sternkopf%40HeartMatterArtworks-12.jpg" style="width: 1200px; height: 802px;" /></p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p><strong>Molly</strong><br />
	Not to be confused with Molly the fine Austrian shoegazers – although, heck, you’d be forgiven for being bewildered – this Molly are a mid-90s US alternative rock band trapped in the bodies of some modern Danish geezers. So, yes, their stuff is wilfully derivative, but it’s all done with loveable lashings of authenticity and enthusiasm; shut your eyes and you could be at a club in Portland in 1993, especially when Molly’s frontman starts riding the crowd.</p>
<p>“He’s not really crowd-surfing,” notes Clash’s companion, ultra-critically. “He’s just being carried around by the same two people.” Well, really.</p>
<p><strong>Velvet Volume</strong><br />
	This three-lass combo – who Clash catches at the unsurprisingly busy Double Rainbow dayparty (‘Free Lunch, Free Beer, Free Coffee,’ said the flyer) - have such a funky poster that you naturally assume that the band must be slightly crap, by comparison. So wrong. From the first few seconds they’re absolutely balls-out tremendous; great rollicking riffs and throbbing bass grooves from a cool-but-fun trio clearly having an absolute ball. Will it work so well on record, though? What’s their sync potential? Who the f*ck cares?</p>
<p><strong>Narcosatanicos</strong><br />
	There’s a curious discussion on the way to this show about what might have happened if the Spice Girls had changed their name to Narcosatanicos immediately after getting world-famous with Wannabe. Would the kids have stuck with them? In fact Narcosatanicos are exactly as you’d expect Narcosatanicos to be: scary-arsed nightmare-inducing jazz-metal noise bandits with really nasty visuals, and absolutely magnificent, if you like that sort of thing.</p>
<p>The Slovenian chap next to Clash looks a bit perturbed, in truth, but turns out he’s not fussed by the unsettling images. He just really hates saxophones.</p>
<p><strong>Kelvin</strong><br />
	The Spot band most likely to have an enormous Europe-wide hit record over the next few years. Kelvin are a clean-cut quintet from the fertile music community of Kristiansand, in southern Norway, who make impressively polished power-pop and are thoroughly diverting live. The youthful backing chaps dress like Rock Jedi while singer Oda Ulvøy could be Taylor Swift’s more energetic younger sister. So, yeah, pretty bloody promising.</p>
<p><strong>Lowly</strong><br />
	Now signed to Bella Union - the indie-band equivalent of being Corgi Registered, or something – the inaptly-named Lowly are actually pretty high-profile here. Still, they had a tough act to follow, given that Clash had just staggered over from the Farveblind headrush in a much more intimate venue.</p>
<p>Lowly work a much larger venue brilliantly though, particularly their simple-but-effective shadow-heavy light show, and the epic final track elicits an emotional standing ovation. Mind you, as the fine comic David O’Doherty says, every performer gets a standing ovation, if they wait around long enough.</p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p>Words: <strong>Si Hawkins</strong></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:49:05 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Si Hawkins</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89882 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/features/the-future-is-nordic-spot-festival-2016#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: Mr. Probz - 'Fine Ass Mess'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-mr-probz-fine-ass-mess</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Screen%20shot%202016-05-12%20at%2017.47.03.png?itok=aJGNfjxT"><a href="/videos/premiere-mr-probz-fine-ass-mess"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Screen%20shot%202016-05-12%20at%2017.47.03.png?itok=aJGNfjxT" width="600" height="600" alt="&#039;Fine Ass Mess&#039;" title="&#039;Fine Ass Mess&#039;" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Dutch house talent hits back...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>Mr. Probz</strong> doesn't let adversity get the better of him.</p>
<p>The Dutch producer has been through it all - bad luck, burglary... fire, even - but he always keep fighting back.</p>
<p>New single 'Fine Ass Mess' is a wry look at his troubles, but that funky beat suggests that he shall overcome.</p>
<p>Out tomorrow (May 13th) Clash has the up-front on the official video. Tune in below.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="300" src="http://cache.vevo.com/assets/html/embed.html?video=NLB8R1600002&amp;partnerId=346c2586-d3f8-4b75-ba0d-398fdb6e4c08" width="480"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:08:01 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89881 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-mr-probz-fine-ass-mess#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: Gundelach - 'Space Echo'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/premiere-gundelach-space-echo</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/unnamed_105.jpg?itok=jlkrpTjL"><a href="/news/premiere-gundelach-space-echo"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/unnamed_105.jpg?itok=jlkrpTjL" width="450" height="300" alt="Gundelach" title="Gundelach" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Norwegian mystery man emerges from the shadows...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>Gundelach</strong> seems to dwell in the shadows, to thrive on suggestion.</p>
<p>A mystery man even in his native Norway, Gundelach introduced himself in late 2015 with the remarkable 'Spiders'.</p>
<p>A radio hit in Scandinavia, word about the artist has blossomed to the extent that he recently performed at Sentrum Scene in Oslo, playing to 1700 people.</p>
<p>Clash is able to premiere new cut 'Space Echo', and it's a marvellous, inspiring piece of electronic music that seems to burst out of its own universe.</p>
<p>Co-produced by Joel Ford, the exactness of the sound is set against an atmosphere that thrives on mystery.</p>
<p>Curiously addictive, it's one to set alongside Laurie Anderson's pop crossover work, for example, or even Kate Bush. Dive in below.</p>
<p><iframe frameborder="no" height="450" scrolling="no" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/263607705%3Fsecret_token%3Ds-PYzED&amp;auto_play=false&amp;hide_related=false&amp;show_comments=true&amp;show_user=true&amp;show_reposts=false&amp;visual=true" width="100%"></iframe></p>
<p>Gundelach's debut EP 'Spiders' drops on May 13th.</p>
<p>Photo Credit: <strong>Simon Skreddernes</strong></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:35:22 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89880 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/premiere-gundelach-space-echo#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: Rothwell - 'Alive' (Live)</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-rothwell-alive-live</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Screen%20shot%202016-05-12%20at%2016.46.39.png?itok=TFNILu_0"><a href="/videos/premiere-rothwell-alive-live"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Screen%20shot%202016-05-12%20at%2016.46.39.png?itok=TFNILu_0" width="600" height="440" alt="Rothwell" title="Rothwell" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">A beautiful and moving performance...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>Rothwell</strong> is a singer-songwriter from Bristol.</p>
<p>That's the prosaic details, the small print. But, as usual, the finer details don't tell you anything you need to know.</p>
<p>The way Rothwell's voice intersects with a song, for example, or the way she can seem to break down with beautifully restrained control.</p>
<p>New EP 'Two' - it's her second, y'see - drops on July 1st, with Clash able to tease something unseen from the Bristol singer.</p>
<p>'Alive' is a wonderful piece of songwriting, all maturity blossoming and potential illuminating.</p>
<p>Shot live, you can tune in below:</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/vK2R9GGQ1Qg" width="560"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:13:20 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89879 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-rothwell-alive-live#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: NINA - 'Beyond Memory'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-nina-beyond-memory</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/NINA_1500x1500.jpg?itok=_hkhjHFg"><a href="/videos/premiere-nina-beyond-memory"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/NINA_1500x1500.jpg?itok=_hkhjHFg" width="600" height="600" alt="&#039;Beyond Memory&#039;" title="&#039;Beyond Memory&#039;" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">An exciting new synth wave talent...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>Richard X</strong> has changed pop more times than anyone can care to remember.</p>
<p>So when the producer decides to get involved with a complete unknown, then our ears prick up.</p>
<p><strong>NINA</strong> is a blossoming synth wave talent, and it seems her promise is being magnified by the acclaimed producer.</p>
<p>NINA: "I'm very excited to have Richard X producing and curating my new release. He is very selective, so I'm humbled to have him on board. He totally gets my vision and my sound. These songs are very close to me, as it was a long creative process to get them how i wanted them, and I opened up to write very personal lyrics."</p>
<p>New cut 'Beyond Memory' is part of their creative relationship. Probing synths and an evocative vocal, it could well be the start of something very special indeed.</p>
<p>Check it out now exclusively on Clash and pre-order the 'Beyond Memory' EP:  <a href="https://itun.es/i6YK9ZK">HERE</a></p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9pItCF_JjJw" width="560"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 15:43:10 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89878 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-nina-beyond-memory#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: SEARLS - 'Demons'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/premiere-searls-demons</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/avatars-000208945542-jsr187-t500x500.jpg?itok=y11WI8DR"><a href="/news/premiere-searls-demons"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/avatars-000208945542-jsr187-t500x500.jpg?itok=y11WI8DR" width="500" height="500" alt="SEARLS" title="SEARLS" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Produced by LJ Looper...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>SEARLS</strong> is an Irish performer, someone who seems to thrive on delving through a state of flux.</p>
<p>Recently partnering up with producer LJ Looper, the pair set about crafting electronic pop vignettes that peppered a universe entirely of their own devising.</p>
<p>New EP 'Follow' is the result. Out on June 17th, it's a bewitching collection of songs that have a vaporous glow.</p>
<p>New cut 'Demons' airs first on Clash, and there's a slight veneer of darkness amidst the beatific electronics.</p>
<p>Check it out now.</p>
<p><iframe frameborder="no" height="450" scrolling="no" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/263738736%3Fsecret_token%3Ds-cuQJv&amp;auto_play=false&amp;hide_related=false&amp;show_comments=true&amp;show_user=true&amp;show_reposts=false&amp;visual=true" width="100%"></iframe></p>

<item>
 <title>Cyndi Lauper - Detour</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/reviews/cyndi-lauper-detour</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Cyndi-Laupers-Detour-Album.jpg?itok=EfYMW1Kp"><a href="/reviews/cyndi-lauper-detour"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/Cyndi-Laupers-Detour-Album.jpg?itok=EfYMW1Kp" width="628" height="628" alt="&#039;Detour&#039;" title="&#039;Detour&#039;" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">A tremendously odd mis-step...</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Ah, Cyndi Lauper. Remember her? That fearless style that inspired generations? The breaking of barriers and rallying cries for female empowerment? That time she told you that your true colours were beautiful like a rainbow and fucking meant it? Remember? Okay, good. But forget all of that now. Girls just wanna have fun — but grown women just want to make wishy washy cover albums. 2010 saw Lauper releasing an album of classic blues covers. Six years later and we’ve been presented with ‘Detour’ - a twee twelve-track record consisting entirely of the ‘She’s So Unusual’ chanteuse singing country songs in a crass New Yoik accent.</p>
<p>Maybe somewhat naively there was an assumption that this record would offer up glimmers of the junk-rock spirit she’d once been famed for, regardless of its genre. Then again, no sane mind could keep from devising that an album from Lauper would at the very least say <em>something</em>. ‘Detour’ initially seemed like an appropriate album title, but perhaps ‘Lost’ is more fitting.</p>
<p>Aside from a few pleasing moments, most of which feature Willie Nelson, the whole thing is very tenuous. Her stabs at reworking Patsy Cline (‘I Fall To Pieces’ and ‘Walkin’ After Midnight’) are admirable but lacking in depth. Rather than ushering in a new wave of substance, ‘You’re The Reason Our Kids Are Ugly’ sees Lauper and Vince Gill colliding over a microphone like Cinzano Rosso-sodden grandparents at a wedding. Her vocals are still knockout in places, but are largely outshone by overproduced, karaoke/Christmas album cushioning.</p>
<p>Poorly executed covers can be excruciating (See: Hilary Duff - ‘My Generation’), but no track on ‘Detour’ comes close to that. In fact, it would do well to rouse any emotion whatsoever. Each song is structured reasonably similar to the original and while she’s brazen in her efforts towards authenticity, for the most part it’s pretty unconvincing. Sure, there’s melodic efficacy, but then she didn’t write the melodies. The lyrics are wistful and alive with narrative, but of course she didn’t write those either. At the very least it was her task to adapt and rework so that the end product amounted to more than just collection of ditties that don’t stand up next to the original. What she’s produced is an album that could’ve been made by anybody else.</p>
<p>Less breaking ground and more cutting a rug across it in someone else’s boots, it feels a lot like Lauper has stalled her own career. It’s impossible to say whether this is premature or not when there’s no recent evidence of artistry to go by. Her history and significance is rooted in rebellion — but that’s easy to overlook with a record this diluted.</p>
<p><strong>4/10</strong></p>
<p>Words: <strong>Maya Rose Radcliffe</strong></p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CYTaiF_Sy10" width="560"></iframe></p>
<p>- - -</p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:52:44 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>ClashMusic</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">89876 at http://www.clashmusic.com</guid>
 <comments>http://www.clashmusic.com/reviews/cyndi-lauper-detour#comments</comments>
</item>
<item>
 <title>Premiere: L.A. Salami - 'The City Nowadays'</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/premiere-la-salami-the-city-nowadays</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/1%20SALAMI-DUOTONE%20m.jpg?itok=oynh8j-6"><a href="/news/premiere-la-salami-the-city-nowadays"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/1%20SALAMI-DUOTONE%20m.jpg?itok=oynh8j-6" width="628" height="942" alt="L.A. Salami" title="L.A. Salami" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">From upcoming album &#039;Bad Grammar&#039;</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>L.A. Salami</strong> was given a guitar for his 21st birthday.</p>
<p>In a way, it was entirely appropriate. The gift seemed to unlock the world of music for him, allowing its puzzles to pour out in the process.</p>
<p>Fast forward by only a few years and L.A. Salami is about to release his debut album. Recorded in a space of just one week, 'Bad Grammar' is sheer post-modern blues, a gritty yet poetic reflection on the world as it is lived.</p>
<p>Fusing together a myriad of different influences, the sound is crisply immediate, with an undercurrent of emotion simply waiting to penetrate the surface.</p>
<p>New cut 'The City Nowadays' is the perfect example. L.A. Salami explains: “I’ve always loved the blues, and I think of this album as my version of blues songs. ‘The City Nowadays’ is like that.”</p>
<p>Bold, entrancing songwriting, you can check it out below.</p>
<p><iframe frameborder="no" height="450" scrolling="no" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/263423438%3Fsecret_token%3Ds-HTFoj&amp;auto_play=true&amp;hide_related=false&amp;show_comments=true&amp;show_user=true&amp;show_reposts=false&amp;visual=true" width="100%"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:40:22 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Robin Murray</dc:creator>

</item>
<item>
 <title>All Saints Want A War - And Now They've Got One</title>
 <link>http://www.clashmusic.com/news/all-saints-want-a-war-and-now-theyve-got-one</link>
 <description><div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" rel="og:image rdfs:seeAlso" resource="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/AF1535_ALL_SAINTS_S10_7249%202_V1_Fin_Colour.jpeg?itok=V10YA7az"><a href="/news/all-saints-want-a-war-and-now-theyve-got-one"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.clashmusic.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_feature/public/field/image/AF1535_ALL_SAINTS_S10_7249%202_V1_Fin_Colour.jpeg?itok=V10YA7az" width="600" height="899" alt="All Saints" title="All Saints" /></a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-article-subtitle field-type-text field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">K-Gee gets to work on &#039;This Is A War&#039;</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><strong>All Saints</strong> were always a little bit different.</p>
<p>Whereas other pop stars preened and posed for the cameras, if this lot didn't fancy it, well, they didn't do it.</p>
<p>Full stop, end of discussion. Delivering perfect pop amid an atmosphere of resolute independence, All Saints seemed to nurture a sense of devotion that many of their rather more artificial peers lacked.</p>
<p>Perhaps this is why the group's reformation has charmed fans. New album 'Red Flag' is out now, with sold out shows finding lines of expectant worshippers snaking round the block.</p>
<p>'This Is A War' seems to follow them wherever they go. A statement of intent, it's a moody piece of pristine melody such as only All Saints can provide.</p>
<p>K-Gee goes to work on the remix, slapping down a hip-hop beat and incorporating new material from Marlon Bernard.</p>
<p>Check it out now.</p>
<p><iframe frameborder="no" height="450" scrolling="no" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/259709289%3Fsecret_token%3Ds-EhjSb&amp;auto_play=false&amp;hide_related=false&amp;show_comments=true&amp;show_user=true&amp;show_reposts=false&amp;visual=true" width="100%"></iframe></p>
<p><u style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); line-height: 20px; font-family: 'Droid Serif', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, 'DejaVu Serif', serif; font-size: 14px; "><strong><a href="http://www.clashmusic.com/tags/issue" style="color: rgb(35, 31, 32); text-decoration: none; "><u><strong>B</strong></u>uy Clash Magazine</a></strong></u></p>
</div></div></div></description>
 <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:23:30 +0000</pubDate>
